evidence.text:
Person A: Boy Willie say he’s going back, but I’m gonna stay. See what it’s like up here.
Person B: You gonna carry me down there first.
Person A: I told you I ain’t going back down there and take a chance on that truck breaking down again. You can take the train. After we sell them watermelons you have enough money you can buy a whole railroad car.
Person A: Lymon think that’s funny. I told the nigger I give him ten dollars to get the brakes fixed. But he thinks that funny.
Person B: Everybody say the Ghosts of the Yellow Dog pushed him.
Person B: My cousin got some land down there. We was helping him.
Person A: Aw hell, Doaker got some of that good whiskey. Don’t give Lymon none of that. He ain’t used to good whiskey. He liable to get sick.
Person B: That’s my uncle. That’s Doaker’s brother. He play piano. He done made some records and everything. He still doing that, Doaker?

Person A: Yeah...look here, Lymon. See how it got all those carvings on it. See, that’s what I was talking about. See how it’s carved up real nice and polished and everything? You never find you another piano like that.
Person A: I told you. My mama used to polish it every day. See all them pictures carved on it? That’s what I was talking about. You can get a nice price for that piano.
Person A: All you got to do is find out who he is and tell him somebody else wanna buy it from you. If he like Doaker say, he’ll give you anything you want for it.
Person A: You want a glass of water, Berniece?
Person B: She don’t need no water. She ain’t seen nothing.

Person A: They found him in his well and all the people say it must be the Ghosts of the Yellow Dog. Just like all them other men.
Person B: Come talking about he looking for me. What he come all the way up here for? If he looking for me all he got to do is wait. He could have saved himself a trip if he looking for me. That ain’t nothing but in Berniece’s head. Ain’t no telling what she liable to come up with next.
Person B: Hey, sugar. Come here and give me a hug. Come on give Uncle Boy Willie a hug. Don’t be shy. Look at her, Doaker. She done got bigger. Ain’t she got big?
Person A: You look just like your mama. I remember you when you was wearing diapers.

Person B: You gonna come down South and see me? Uncle Boy Willie gonna get him a farm. Gonna get a great big old farm. Come down there and I’ll teach you how to ride a mule. Teach you how to kill a chicken, too.
Person A: She getting big, Doaker. You remember her, Lymon?
Person B: I remember when you was down there on the Wilshaw place planting cotton. You wasn’t thinking about no Reverend then.
Person A: I see why you gonna call it the Good Shepherd Church. You dreaming about them sheep people. I can see that easy.
Person A: Lymon nothing. You go down there and sleep in it. I ain’t sleeping in no truck.
Person B: You done been there for real, Wining Boy?
Person B: As soon as Stovall turned his back, Lymon was gone. He down there living in that truck dodging the sheriff and Stovall. So I brought him up here.

Person A: That’s why you gonna end up back down there on the Parchman Farm.
Person A: They work you too hard down there. All that weeding and hoeing and chopping down trees. I didn’t like all that.

Person A: That’s what they told Lymon. They had Lymon on water and everybody got mad at him ‘cause he was lazy.
Person A: They had Lymon down there singing. O Lord Berta Berta O Lord gal oh-ah O Lord Berta Berta O Lord gal well

Person A: Doaker like that part. He like that railroad part.
Person A: Hey, Doaker, they still talk about you down on Parchman. They ask me, “You Doaker Boy’s nephew?” I say, “Yeah, me and him is family.” They treated me alright soon as I told them that. Say, “Yeah, he my uncle.”
Person B: Whoever playing better play quick. Sutter’s brother say he waiting on me. I sell them watermelons. Get Berniece to sell that piano. Put them two parts with the part I done saved...

Person B: You stay! I’m going back! That’s what I’m gonna do with my life! Why I got to come up here and learn to do something I don’t know how to do when I already know how to farm? You stay up here and make your own way if that’s what you want to do. I’m going back and live my life the way I want to live it.
Person B: It wasn’t that heavy to me. Okay let’s put it back.

Person A: Me and Boy Willie told him about the wood. We told him some fellows might be trying to beat us to it. He say let me go back and get my thirty-eight. That’s what caused all the trouble.
Person A: We had it about half loaded when they come up on us. We seen the sheriff with them and we tried to get away. We ducked around near the bend in the creek...but they was down there too. Boy Willie say let’s give in. But Crawley pulled out his gun and started shooting. That’s when they started shooting back.
Person B: Them white folks is something else...ain’t they, Lymon?
Person A: I’m still looking. That ain’t all you got either. Where’s all them quarters?
Person A: How this look, Boy Willie?
Person B: That look nice...if you like that kind of thing. I don’t like them dress up kind of clothes. If you like it, look real nice.

Person A: Hey, Lymon, how many of them watermelons would you say we got left? We got just under a half a load...right?
Person B: About that much. Maybe a little more.
Person B: If we stack them watermelons you can sit it up in the front there.
Person A: I’m gonna call that man tomorrow.

Person B: Why you leave last night, I looked around and you was gone.
Person A: I come back here with Grace, then I went looking for you.
Person B: I come back here looking for you!
Person B: Just lift up on that end, nigger! Doaker comes to the doorway of his room and stands with the gun at his side.
Person B: Give me that rope and get up on this side of the piano.
Person B: Let me worry about the rope. You just get up on this side over here with me.
Person A: I’m through talking to Berniece. Get up on that side, Lymon.
Person B: You sure you want to do this? The way I figure it...I might be wrong...but I figure she gonna shoot you first.
